current_fact.fact_text: On 25 January 1858, Felix Mendelssohn’s “Wedding March” was performed at the marriage of Queen Victoria’s daughter Victoria to Prince Friedrich of Prussia. The royal spotlight turned a piece from Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream into the default soundtrack of Western weddings for more than a century.

episode.title: Sedna FM #04 - Queen of Spades
episode.description: Tuning in from the planet of irrational love. Exploring love's most vulnerable side — the kind that awakens the child within us. A diverse music selection ranging from electric blues to downtempo, soul, and jazz. A tribute to the feeling that has moved artists to create the most beautiful works. Love makes us vulnerable, and there is no art without vulnerability.
songs: Alabama Shakes - Gimme All Your Love
Queens of the stone age - Make it wit chu
Etta James - I'd Rather Go Blind
Eric Clapton - Have you ever loved a woman

current_fact.match_reason: A royal wedding that reshaped the sound of romance pairs with an episode devoted to love’s music, from grand gestures to vulnerable, private feelings.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1937, the soap opera Guiding Light first aired on NBC radio in Chicago, following the moral and emotional struggles of a Midwestern minister. It migrated to television in 1952 and ran until 2009, becoming one of the longest-running drama series in broadcast history and quietly chronicling everyday lives for over seven decades.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb
episode.description: The first Family & Friends radio episode from Yasmin Sarbaoui and Gaia Parolini. Where it all began — a life soundtrack that launched Sedna FM into the universe. Raw, heartfelt, and full of the energy that defines everything that followed.
songs: Canserbero - De la vida como pelicula, tragedia, comedia y ficcion

queue.match_reason: The birth of a long-running radio drama aligns with Sedna FM’s own origin episode, both marking the start of storytelling worlds built through sound and recurring voices.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1960, the U.S. National Association of Broadcasters responded to the exploding "payola" scandal by threatening fines for disc jockeys who secretly took money to spin certain records. The crackdown reshaped radio playlists, raising questions about who really decides what becomes a hit: listeners, artists, or quiet payments behind the scenes.

episode.title: Morning Drops #08 - (un)Boxing
episode.description: An episode about breaking free from expectations and labels. Music that helps us unbox ourselves and embrace who we truly are.
songs: Kendrick Lamar - The Blacker the Berry

queue.match_reason: A scandal that exposed the manipulation behind which songs get played fits an episode about breaking from imposed boxes and questioning who sets the rules.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1961, Walt Disney’s "One Hundred and One Dalmatians" premiered, pioneering a new Xerox-based animation technique that allowed sketchy, energetic linework to appear directly on screen. Its stylized London, jazz-tinged score, and spotted canine swarm helped pull Disney into a more modern era of animation.

episode.title: Morning Drops #38 - History of Flamenco
episode.description: A special journey into the history of Flamenco, guided by Yasmin and her guest Almudena from Madrid, Spain. Exploring the roots and evolution of this emotionally raw and culturally rich tradition, from its early vocal origins and Andalusian influences, through its transformation on stage and screen, to its modern reinventions by iconic Spanish artists.
songs: La Niña de los Peines - Al Gurugú
Paco de Lucía - Entre dos aguas
Camarón de la Isla - La leyenda del tiempo

queue.match_reason: Both the film and the episode trace how an art form evolves—from classical roots to stylized modernity—through bold visual and musical innovation.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1348, a powerful earthquake shook the Eastern Alps near Friuli, Italy, causing destruction so widespread that reports came from as far as Rome and Bohemia. Medieval observers struggled to explain the disaster, often weaving it into religious and apocalyptic narratives.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas
episode.description: Yasmin's friend Caroline takes us beyond the polar circle, into the Arctic waters of Norway, where orcas and humpback whales gather each winter. A personal journey shaped by a quiet obsession with orcas, from Patagonia to the icy fjords of the north. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

queue.match_reason: A dramatic natural event in Italy meets a cinematic, nature-focused episode; both invite awe at Earth’s forces, from shifting plates to roaming whales.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1999, a magnitude 6-plus earthquake struck western Colombia, devastating the coffee-growing city of Armenia and surrounding towns. Beyond the thousands of casualties, it triggered a massive reconstruction effort and new thinking about how to build resilient communities in seismic regions.

episode.title: Morning Drops #45 - It Can't Rain Forever
episode.description:
In this first broadcast of 2026, Gaia returns from the vivid landscapes of Morocco to open a space for reflection. This episode navigates the delicate transition between closing a significant chapter and stepping into the new year. It explores the concept of constancy amidst change, celebrating the grounding force of friendship and the creative sanctuary that is Sedna FM.

The musical selection mirrors this journey, moving from the orchestral depth of changing seasons into the golden warmth of psychedelic soul. It recalls memories of Swiss mountains and unexpected downpours, reminding us that shared optimism can weather any storm.

Take a moment to breathe in the new morning and listen deeply.

Mood: Reflective, Warm, Transitional, Hopeful
Music genre: Classic Rock, Psychedelic Soul, Pop Rock, Soft Rock

queue.match_reason: An earthquake that forces a region to rebuild connects with an episode about weathering storms and finding hope and continuity after upheaval.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1979, Pope John Paul II began his first official trips outside Italy, visiting the Bahamas, the Dominican Republic, and Mexico. The youthful, charismatic pontiff drew unprecedented crowds and used these journeys to turn the papacy into a highly visible, globe-trotting moral voice.

episode.title: Morning Drops #39 - Moving Meditation
episode.description: An episode inspired by how travel helps us see more clearly. Stepping into new places opens the mind, shifts perspective. The music moves through balearic warmth, boogie grooves, world and latin-folk influences, and touches of new wave — a selection built to follow the quiet changes that happen when you're out of your usual rhythm.
songs: España Circo Este - Dormo poco e sogno molto
Talking Heads - This Must Be the Place (Naive Melody)

queue.match_reason: A pope redefining his role through travel pairs naturally with an episode that treats journeys themselves as meditative, mind-shifting experiences.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1704, British colonial forces and their Muscogee allies attacked the Spanish mission of Ayubale in Florida, an event remembered as the Apalachee massacre. The raid shattered Spain’s fragile mission network and opened the way for British dominance in the region, at enormous cost to indigenous communities.

episode.title: Morning Drops #16 - The Sound of Tuareg
episode.description: A journey into the sound of the Tuareg: from traditional chants and desert rituals to the electrified rhythms of exile and resistance. Music shaped by sand, memory, and survival.

queue.match_reason: A violent colonial incursion that reshaped indigenous lives resonates with an episode focused on music born from desert survival, displacement, and resistance.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January AD 41, after the assassination of Emperor Caligula, the Roman Senate hesitated over restoring the Republic until they discovered his timid uncle Claudius hiding behind a curtain. The Praetorian Guard proclaimed him emperor, showing how raw military power could elevate an unlikely, underestimated figure to rule the ancient superpower.

episode.title: Morning Drops #30 - Star Treatment
episode.description: A celebration of change and transformation. Gaia traces the evolution of Arctic Monkeys - from raw energy to cinematic sound - reflecting on how artists, and all of us, grow and change through time. A journey through courage, curiosity, and the beauty of slowing down.
songs: Arctic Monkeys - There’d Better Be a Mirrorball

queue.match_reason: Claudius’ sudden elevation from sidelined relative to emperor reflects the theme of transformation and unexpected ‘star treatment’ explored through artistic evolution.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1980, Mother Teresa was awarded India’s highest civilian honor, the Bharat Ratna, in recognition of her work with the poorest in Kolkata. The tiny nun's image became a global symbol of service and compassion, sparking both admiration and debate about the nature of charity.

episode.title: Sedna FM #03 - Beautiful as You Feel
episode.description: An episode about self-acceptance and inner beauty. Music that reminds us we are beautiful as we feel, embracing our authentic selves. Warm, uplifting sounds that celebrate individuality.
songs: The The - this is the day
DCTL - Deep Tannin f(eat Rafael Leafar)

queue.match_reason: An award honoring a life of service ties to an episode that celebrates inner beauty and the quiet strength that doesn’t depend on status or appearance.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1942, Thailand formally declared war on both the United States and the United Kingdom, aligning itself with Imperial Japan during World War II. The move reflected the country’s attempt to navigate survival between empires, a decision later revisited in postwar politics and memory.

episode.title: Morning Drops #35 - Thailand
episode.description: Recorded in Koh Samui, Thailand, where Yasmin and her friend Patricia spent more than two intense weeks training Muay Thai and Western boxing. Between sweat, rhythm, and sea breeze, they share reflections on discipline, friendship, and the beauty of movement - with a soundtrack that connects Thai sounds to the flow of daily practice.
songs: Burna Boy - Cheat on Me (feat. Dave)

queue.match_reason: A pivotal wartime decision by Thailand is paired with an episode recorded in contemporary Thailand, linking the country’s turbulent past to its vibrant present culture.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1918, the newly independent Finland created its official army by recognizing the White Guards as the Finnish Defence Forces and appointing C. G. E. Mannerheim as commander-in-chief. The step came on the eve of civil war, as the young nation tried to define its identity and security amid revolution and foreign pressure.

episode.title: Morning Drops #20 - Hitchhiking Poland
episode.description: Yasmin takes you back to the summer of 2020, when borders were still uncertain and a long-held wish to visit Poland finally came true. Through four tracks, tracing her journey from a stranger's couch in Poznań to the peaks of Zakopane.

queue.match_reason: An emerging nation in Northern Europe defining its borders and identity resonates with an Eastern European travel episode exploring place, history, and movement across frontiers.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1909, Richard Strauss’s opera "Elektra" premiered at the Dresden State Opera, shocking audiences with its dissonant harmonies, psychological intensity, and almost unrelenting orchestral power. The radical score pushed late-Romantic music to its breaking point and paved the way for modernism in the concert hall.

episode.title: Morning Drops #05 - Electric Shock
episode.description: An energizing episode with electrifying sounds to wake you up and get you moving. High energy tracks that deliver a jolt of musical electricity to start your day.

queue.match_reason: A jarring, high-voltage opera debut matches an episode built on electrifying, guitar-driven shockwaves that rewire how you experience sound.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1949, the very first Emmy Awards ceremony took place at the Hollywood Athletic Club, honoring local Los Angeles television programs in a fledgling medium. From that modest night, the Emmys grew into one of the major global awards, charting television’s rise from curiosity to cultural powerhouse.

episode.title: Morning Drops #12 - 80's Club
episode.description: Starting with a Monday evening in Munich — a few drinks, friends, and landing in an 80s dance party. From Donna Summer's hypnotic pulse, to Depeche Mode's bright synthpop, Ken Laszlo's Italo Disco romance, and Mylène Farmer's darker theatrical world. Four songs, four corners of the 80s — connected by the machines that changed how we dance.
songs: Depeche Mode - Just Can't Get Enough

queue.match_reason: The birth of a TV award that would later celebrate countless shows pairs with an episode rooted in 1980s pop culture—the era when television and synth-driven music intertwined on screens worldwide.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1932, during the early clashes that foreshadowed the Second Sino-Japanese War, the National Revolutionary Army began defending Harbin against Japanese-backed forces. The struggle illustrated how northeastern China became a testing ground for tactics and ambitions that would soon erupt into a full-scale regional war.

episode.title: Morning Drops #25 - A Trip-Hop Journey
episode.description: Hosted by friend Lorenzo, a journey through the roots and evolution of trip-hop. From Bristol's early experiments with Massive Attack and Tricky, to DJ Shadow's cinematic sampling in California, and Thievery Corporation's global downtempo grooves in Washington D.C. — exploring how this genre blurred boundaries and reshaped electronic music.
songs: Tricky - Hell Is Round the Corner
DJ Shadow - Midnight in a Perfect World

queue.match_reason: A cold, cinematic battle in Manchuria echoes the moody, atmospheric storytelling of trip‑hop, where slow tension and layered textures reveal deeper conflicts.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 2013, a riot in Uribana prison in Barquisimeto, Venezuela, left at least 50 people dead and scores wounded after a planned weapons search spiraled into chaos. The tragedy drew attention to overcrowding, gang control, and human rights abuses in the country’s prison system.

episode.title: Morning Drops #26 - Canserbero
episode.description: Yasmin guides us through the story of Canserbero, the Venezuelan rapper who reshaped Latin American hip hop with his raw voice and deeply reflective lyrics. A journey into his music, his vision, and the legacy of an artist who transformed personal and social struggles into powerful storytelling.
songs: Canserbero - De la vida como una película y su tragedia, comedia y ficción

queue.match_reason: A Venezuelan prison disaster demanding reflection on violence and injustice is paired with an episode dedicated to a Venezuelan artist who confronted precisely those themes through rap.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1947, physicist Thomas T. Goldsmith Jr. filed a patent for the "Cathode Ray Tube Amusement Device," an early analog game where players twiddled knobs to aim artillery at targets drawn on a screen. Though never commercially released, it’s widely regarded as the first electronic game, ancestor to the entire video game universe.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.

queue.match_reason: The first experimental electronic game arose from playful tinkering and iterative design, echoing the episode’s celebration of curiosity, trial-and-error, and the joy of learning.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1909, while Europe still echoed with opera like Strauss’s "Elektra," another quiet revolution was underway in how we remember moments: the widespread adoption of film and photography was beginning to change how performances, wars, and daily life were documented. This technological shift gradually transformed memory into something replayable.

episode.title: Morning Drops #43 - Looking Back
episode.description:
In this first Morning Drop of 2026, Yasmin opens a space for quiet reflection on the nature of transitions. The episode traces a personal journey that began three years ago, when a sudden injury on New Year’s Day turned a desire for movement into a mandatory season of stillness.

Through the story of a broken knee and the slow process of relearning to walk, the narrative explores the difference between being strong and being aware. It touches on the vulnerability of the body, the unexpected joy found in daily progress, and the warmth that comes from finally allowing oneself to accept help. The musical selection mirrors this path of recovery, moving from the uncertainty of change to the steady rhythm of healing.

Mood: Reflective, Resilient, Grounded
Music genre: Indie Pop, Cinematic, World, Soul

We invite you to listen deeply and find comfort in your own pace.
songs: Kelly Finnigan - I Don't Wanna Wait
Goran Bregović & Iggy Pop - This Is a Film

queue.match_reason: A world increasingly able to replay its memories resonates with an introspective episode about looking back, replaying a difficult chapter, and seeing it with new awareness.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1942, while Thailand’s declaration of war rippled across the Pacific, wartime radio was rapidly becoming a lifeline between fronts and home. Music, news, and propaganda floated across shortwave bands, turning sound into both comfort and a tool of influence on a planetary scale.

episode.title: Sedna FM #05 - On The Go - Zero Zero
episode.description: An energetic mix for when you're on the move. Zero Zero captures that feeling of starting fresh, moving forward, and embracing the journey. Perfect for travel, walks, or just getting things done.
songs: Grace Jones - Pull up to the bumper
Easy star all star - Soul love
James Brown - Talking loud and saying nothing (remix)

queue.match_reason: As radio waves carried wartime messages and songs across borders, an upbeat, travel-ready mix captures the sense of motion and sonic connectivity that defined the era’s airwaves.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1937, as "Guiding Light" debuted, countless households began gathering around the radio at the same time every day, sharing a collective ritual of serial storytelling. This practice turned domestic space into a tiny theatre and set the stage for the binge-worthy series culture we know today.

episode.title: Morning Drops #01 - Timeless Legacy
episode.description: Gaia guides us through timeless music to start the morning with the right foot! The first episode of the Morning Drops series — classic sounds that never fade.
songs: Roberta Flack - Killing me softly with his song

queue.match_reason: A daily ritual built around sound and story fits an episode celebrating timeless tracks—music that, like long-running radio dramas, never really leaves the room.

queue.fact_text: On 25 January 1994, as Clementine set off for the Moon, engineers and scientists were quietly testing how machines could extend human senses into deep space. That mission hinted at a future where exploration means collaborating with technology to see, map, and feel places our bodies may never reach.

episode.title: Sedna FM #02 - Destination Sedna
episode.description: Continuing the Sedna FM journey together with family and friends! Episode two of the main series — exploring new musical territories and deepening the connection with our listeners. A collective voyage through sound.
songs: Odion Iruoje - Identify With Your Roots
Depeche mode - world in my eyes (Oil Tank Mix)

queue.match_reason: A spacecraft voyaging into lunar orbit aligns with a Sedna FM episode explicitly framed as a journey to a distant destination through sound and imagination.

published.fact_text: On 25 January 2018, an Ariane 5 rocket launched from French Guiana carrying the SES-14 and Al Yah 3 communications satellites, along with NASA’s GOLD space weather instrument. A guidance error sent the payloads into the wrong orbit, but engineers used onboard propulsion to slowly correct their paths, turning what looked like a failure into a creative orbital rescue.

episode.title: Morning Drops #03 - Space Shift
episode.description: Gaia invites you to shift your mindset with a simple yet powerful reflection: What if we saw emptiness not as a void but as space to create? An energising and feel-good selection of tracks, the perfect way to ease into your day and set the tone for the week ahead.
songs: Willy J Healey - Woke Up Smiling
The Strokes - You Only Live Once

published.match_reason: A misrouted rocket that still finds its path mirrors the episode’s theme of reframing emptiness and detours as creative space to shift direction.

published.fact_text: On 25 January 1995, a Norwegian scientific rocket called Black Brant XII nearly triggered nuclear war when Russian early-warning systems mistook it for a U.S. Trident missile. For a tense few minutes, the nuclear briefcase was opened and launch options were considered before scientists confirmed it was just an aurora-research flight.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

published.match_reason: A single misunderstood signal almost triggered catastrophe; this pairs with an episode about how our relationship with technology and signals shapes our perceptions and fears.

published.fact_text: On 25 January 1994, the joint BMDO–NASA spacecraft Clementine launched to test advanced sensors while mapping the Moon in unprecedented detail. It famously found strong evidence of water ice in permanently shadowed lunar craters, turning the Moon from a dry rock into a potentially resource-rich outpost in humanity’s imagination.

episode.title: Evening Flows #01 - Yasmin - Crescendo in the Medina
episode.description: The first Evening Flow episode comes from Yasmin. It starts deep in the medina, slow, mysterious, textured, and grows into a liberating dance across sub-Saharan landscapes. A journey through ambient soundscapes, Arabic melodies, Afro-Latin rhythms, and funky highlife grooves.
songs: David Visan & Carlos Campos - Crystal Heart
Evan Mars - Ya Zareef Al Tool
Dele Sosimi & Medlar - You No Fit Touch Am (Medlar Remix)

published.match_reason: Clementine’s quiet orbit around the Moon, sensing hidden landscapes, fits the episode’s slow-build journey from mystery to expansive motion across distant terrains.

published.fact_text: On 25 January 1858, Felix Mendelssohn’s “Wedding March” was performed at the marriage of Queen Victoria’s daughter Victoria to Prince Friedrich of Prussia. The royal spotlight turned a piece from Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream into the default soundtrack of Western weddings for more than a century.

episode.title: Sedna FM #04 - Queen of Spades
episode.description: Tuning in from the planet of irrational love. Exploring love's most vulnerable side — the kind that awakens the child within us. A diverse music selection ranging from electric blues to downtempo, soul, and jazz. A tribute to the feeling that has moved artists to create the most beautiful works. Love makes us vulnerable, and there is no art without vulnerability.
songs: Alabama Shakes - Gimme All Your Love
Queens of the stone age - Make it wit chu
Etta James - I'd Rather Go Blind
Eric Clapton - Have you ever loved a woman

published.match_reason: A royal wedding that reshaped the sound of romance pairs with an episode devoted to love’s music, from grand gestures to vulnerable, private feelings.
